A. James Clark School of Engineering.review: Fun, educational, useful in industry, flexible
I thoroughly enjoy my job and responsibilities

Accounting.review: I really like the job, getting to teach new students is pretty rewarding and it is also good practice for those planning on taking the CPA exam.

Year long commitment. Includes 5 office hours, 2 discussion sections to teach, class attendance, slide prep for weekly discussion sections (which you can get from someone who previously was a TA for the class), and grading/entering quizzes into elms/canvas. Also need to proctor exams throughout the semester. I have loved and enjoyed the experience because it is fantastic prep for the FAR section of the CPA exam. It also helps you get ready for the work world and the ability to explain accounting concepts to people with no prior experience with accounting. It is more work than other TA jobs (I am basing this off my friends who TA for different classes) but I enjoy doing it so I really don't mind the extra work.

Clarice Smith Performing Arts Center.review: This is a great place to work because you get to pick your own hours, and it gives you the chance to work on shows even if you aren’t a theater major. They pay undergraduate students minimum wage.

College of Computer, Math & Natural Scie.review: Being a Peer Advisor (PA) is a customer service job where you spend most of your time answering emails and phone calls for the department. In terms of benefits, the job is quite relaxed — once you answer all the emails on shift you essentially have nothing to do and can do anything from homework to watching Netflix. You may not enjoy the job if you have difficulty with customer service skills like working calmly with frustrated students or stubborn parents, as you'll often get phone calls from unhappy people.

Computer Science.review: The pay is decent, we also have more control over the class than a normal TA, so the professor only does the administrative stuff.
Great job, Goldstein is a great faculty advisor who cares about his students
super chill and fun job open-ended

Couns Ctr.review: Good on campus job, my boss very respectful of my schedule and understands the student pressures. also pays well and is fun to get steps in yeet

DS.review: I imagine its the same as any other food service job. It does not have very many benefits other than I can pick up shifts as I need which is helpful for my schedule. I will say I dislike how there is no way to know what hours go into what paycheck.

Dean.review: I love my job and I think I get paid well

Engineering Information Technology.review: An exciting job for those who like working with their hands. Lots of great people involved.

Great place to work. Employees learn a lot about additive and subtractive manufacturing, as well as how to design parts with these processes in mind. Great opportunity to connect with professors and research groups. Every project is different so employees get a variety of challenges that promote education and self discipline

ICA.review: Absolutely fantastic job within the Athletics Department office of Facilities Operations and Events. If you enjoy sports, would like a job that requires some physicality and involves problem solving this is the place. The bosses are young and nice, very accommodating for school and there’s only a one shift a week requirement.

Office of Multi.job_title: Team Leader at College Success Scholars
Office of Multi.review: It’s a very rewarding job as you get to work closely with other team leaders and provide guidance to younger students. It’s a very tight knit community and the people there are passionate about improving the program

Office of Student Conduct.review: Great introduction to administrative and customer service skills. Taught me how to be patient and kind over the phone especially. Lays a great foundation for future office or admin work. Wonderful work environment for how scary sounding the office is.

Philip Merrill College of Journalism.job_title: Student Supervisor in Residential Facilities (Promotion from Desk Assosicate)
Philip Merrill College of Journalism.review:
Pros: Fair and kind boss, very flexible hours, raises and promotions possible, good experience (costumer service skills, phone skills, paperwork, handling emergencies)
Cons: long and complex training process

Great campus job, can't really complain because we don't do much of anything. Lots of time to work on homework and get to know faculty, and there's a super welcoming environment. Tasks include answering the phone, delivering mail, and scheduling advising appointments.
Good job, fun times, bosses and other casters are a joy to work with, everyone is very relaxed.

RL.review: It was a decent job but the management filled time with unnecessary tasks occasionally

Not the worst job on campus, however the odd hours and inflexibility is concerning at times. A great job if you get placed at a desk with a lot of involvement, but I worked at Leonardtown, and our lack of employees meant a lack of coverage, which often meant that I was stuck working 3-6am on a weekly basis, which was detrimental to my school work and mental health. Other weird expectations were to stay at the desk if the next community assist at (CA) did not show up, and that requirement came with no limit, and no excuses, meaning you could be fired for abandoning the desk even if your shift was over, and you had class etc. However these kind of situations hardly ever came up, and it was mostly a very chill job that allowed me to do homework and still make some extra cash. Also a great way to interact with people if you’re a people person!

Res Facilities.review: DO NOT work here. it is so draining and management is so manipulative. 0/10, do NOT recommend. It may seem like a good choice at first, but it's not. Get out while you can

the worst place to work. its not even on campus, its across campus by leonardtown which is far from a lot of it. the other desk staff are problematic and management does not know how to keep students motivated to work here. burnout is real here. I do not recommend it here

Robert H. Smith School of Business.review:
The amount of time I had to commit to this job this week was highly variable. There would be periods where I was big chilling and other stretches of time (midterms, finals, etc.) where I had way too many tasks to fulfill. 

Regardless, the tasks I was assigned to were fairly simple; grading student’s assignments and tracking attendance and participation were my main areas of focus.

Given the administrative nature of my role, however, I often felt underemployed and quite frankly, bored lol. This boredom would sometimes lead to me contemplating my life decisions instead of listening to my students and doing my job. 

My professor was great, so I think my issue aligned more so with the course I was helping with. 

Therefore, I would urge students to only TA for a course that they’re interested in. Otherwise, you might start sleeping in class with the rest of your bored students who are also contemplating their lives.

Robert H. Smith School of Business.job_title: Office of Career Services Front Desk Assistant
Robert H. Smith School of Business.review: I have been enjoying the job, I don't usually have too much to do unless there are a lot of employers on campus. I just wish things were communicated a bit better between the students and advisors though. Sometimes I feel like we're supposed to be doing certain things that weren't directly told to us. And then it's super stressful trying to figure out what needs to get done

SU.review: I like the job because it’s easy and I can do my homework at the desk. I think I get paid appropriately for what I do

Pretty easy work, very manual, flexible hours—only hard when there’s a lot of stuff going on with clubs/organizations primarily at the beginning and end of semesters when a lot of the rooms in stamp are rented back to back

On top of getting access to a lot of nice events that happen at STAMP, you have the ability to work in a practical IT role with mentors that guide you and help you learn. The coworkers are also chill and theres a lot of opportunities for you to meet new people if you like that!
Nice opportunity, you have the ability to learn a lot about a practical IT role in a setting with supervisors who are willing to assist you in learning.

Stamp Union.review: great workplace environment! fairly easy, straightforward job, easy to work and do schoolwork

The shifts are three hours long and you have to do about 15 minutes of work during that time. The processes of checking out keys, swipes, and packages are confusing to learn (because it’s unnecessarily complicated), but once you do it’s easy. The rest of the shift you can do whatever you want like homework or Netflix. The worst part are the graves. You have to work one every two weeks, between midnight and 9am. If you get stuck with a 3am to 6am, good luck trying to keep a normal schedule the next day. This job is good for night owls looking for easy money.

Honestly not a bad job. Some shifts can be overwhelming depending on the amount of events in stamp. Work environment is really friendly everyone is respectful and gets along very well. Boss is pretty understanding most of the time with scheduling.

University Recreation & Wellness.review: This was a great job with super flexible hours. You can schedule the times that you teach and there's plenty of opportunity for growth + to gain more certifications, including CPR, AED, Water Safety Instruction, and Lifeguarding.

I really enjoy working in the club sports office. There is a really positive and friendly environment and it really assists with my duties as a club sport member. I feel compensated for the work I do although I wish there were more opportunities to work more hours.

Good benefits if you’re big into cycling, access to S-Tec, Wahoo, SRAM, and other bike component discounts. Quality training sessions and nice staff. Workload can be pretty tough depending on the day and time of the year. First and last weeks of the semester can become very hectic and you can be working nonstop while other times you’ll just do 1 repair during your shift.

The community at Eppley is great. I love my coworkers so much. I didn't feel like I belonged at UMD until I was hired at Eppley as Facilities Staff during my Spring semester of freshman year. There's some room for growth, too, within my position, which makes me feel good about the progress I make at work. I really enjoy my time on shift, especially because of my peers.
However, the professional staff are terrible. They do not care about students. The majority of professional staff actively fight against raising our wages. In my position specifically, we have been threatened with shift and staff cuts because some supervisors were on their phones more than pro staff liked. There are very contentious relationships between pro staff and student staff; we aren't treated like real workers, instead like children who can't properly care for a building.
I am very reluctant to interact with male staff at times because of the awful encounters so many of the female staff have had with men in Eppley.
Most of the students are great; the professional staff are god awful.
easy job, nice coworkers, good management, and good pay. downside is when you’re new, you get stuck with the worst hours, and that can be pretty rough.

I have honestly loved this job. Met so many great people and learned a lot. Currently there’s a shift shortage because too many people were hired last season but that’s really my only major complaint.

RecWell has always been a safe space as an on-campus space and employment opportunity for me, but it is not without it's faults. When you first start, it can seem overwhelming but I promise it's worth it. That being said, as you get promoted to supervisor and take on leadership roles within the department, you get to see a lot under the cover. The professional staff who oversee RecWell are extremely opinionated and selfish for their own students, and often do not work together when it's needed most which is disheartening. Good work schedule flexibility and pay, but be prepared to deal with a high level of interpersonal politics.
i really appreciate this job and all the people i have met through it, it has really changed my college experience and i am thankful for it

I love working at Eppley. I love getting to meet new people all of the time and think I have gained a lot of customer service/ people skills from it. It has brought me another community at UMD that I can be myself at.
Good work environment, heavily dependent on time of year you work (first and last couple weeks of school gets very hectic). Good support for mechanics and useful training sessions.

VP Administration.job_title: student assistant at the registrar’s office
VP Administration.review: it’s a pretty chill job. for the first couple months, while i was still getting trained to use the phones, i worked at the front desk doing identification cards and verification forms. it only really becomes busy at the beginning and end of the semester including academic deadlines. when you work on the phones you really get a lot of time to also work on your school work. plus everyone is really nice an$ welcoming there.
